quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 11: Unit 3 Quiz 7
quiz.subtitle: 3.7: Bond Angles and Distortion from Ideal Geometry
quiz.subject: Chemistry

questions.question: Why is the bond angle in Water ($104.5^\circ$) smaller than the ideal tetrahedral angle ($109.5^\circ$)?
options: Lone pairs occupy more space and compress the bonding pairs together
Oxygen is more electronegative than Hydrogen
The Hydrogen atoms are attracted to each other
The $s$ and $p$ orbitals do not overlap correctly
questions.explanation: Lone pairs are held closer to the nucleus and spread out more than bonding pairs, exerting greater repulsion that 'squeezes' the bonds closer.

questions.question: Which of the following ranks the magnitude of electron group repulsions correctly?
options: Lone pair-Lone pair > Lone pair-Bonding pair > Bonding pair-Bonding pair
Bonding pair-Bonding pair > Lone pair-Bonding pair > Lone pair-Lone pair
Lone pair-Bonding pair > Lone pair-Lone pair > Bonding pair-Bonding pair
All electron group repulsions are equal in magnitude
questions.explanation: Lone pairs are the most repulsive because they are not confined between two nuclei, followed by the interaction between a lone pair and a bond.

questions.question: In the molecule Formaldehyde ($CH_2O$), how does the double bond affect the $H-C-H$ bond angle?
options: The $H-C-H$ angle is smaller than $120^\circ$ because the double bond repels the single bonds more strongly
The $H-C-H$ angle is exactly $120^\circ$
The $H-C-H$ angle is larger than $120^\circ$ due to the size of the Oxygen atom
The double bond has no effect on the bond angles
questions.explanation: Multiple bonds contain higher electron density than single bonds and exert more repulsion, pushing the $C-H$ bonds closer together.

questions.question: Comparing Ammonia ($NH_3$) and Water ($H_2O$), which has the smaller bond angle?
options: Water, because it has two lone pairs instead of one
Ammonia, because Nitrogen is less electronegative than Oxygen
They have the same bond angle because both are based on a tetrahedron
Ammonia, because it has more Hydrogen atoms
questions.explanation: Every additional lone pair adds more repulsive force against the bonding pairs. Water (2 lone pairs) compresses the angle more than Ammonia (1 lone pair).

questions.question: What happens to the bond angle as the electronegativity of the central atom increases (keeping terminal atoms the same)?
options: The bond angle generally increases
The bond angle generally decreases
The bond angle remains constant
The molecule becomes linear
questions.explanation: A more electronegative central atom pulls bonding electrons closer to itself, increasing electron density near the center and causing more repulsion between bonds.

questions.question: In a 'See-saw' molecular geometry ($AX_4E$), which angles are most likely to be distorted from their ideal values?
options: Both the $180^\circ$ (axial) and $120^\circ$ (equatorial) angles
Only the $180^\circ$ axial angle
Only the $120^\circ$ equatorial angle
None, the angles remain ideal
questions.explanation: The lone pair in the equatorial position pushes both the other equatorial bonds and the axial bonds away, distorting all ideal angles.

questions.question: Which molecule would you expect to have a bond angle closest to the ideal $109.5^\circ$?
options: $SiH_4$
$NCl_3$
questions.explanation: Silicon tetrahydride has four identical bonding pairs and no lone pairs, so it maintains a perfect tetrahedral symmetry.

questions.question: How does the size of terminal (outer) atoms affect bond angles?
options: Larger terminal atoms generally increase the bond angle due to steric bulk
Larger terminal atoms decrease the bond angle
Terminal atom size has no effect on VSEPR shapes
Larger atoms pull the central atom toward them
questions.explanation: Steric repulsion (physical space occupied by large atoms) can force atoms further apart, increasing the bond angle.

questions.question: In the molecule $SO_2$, the $O-S-O$ angle is approximately $117^\circ$. This distortion from $120^\circ$ is due to:
options: One lone pair on the Sulfur atom
The presence of two double bonds
The high electronegativity of Oxygen
The $d$-orbitals of Sulfur
questions.explanation: Sulfur has three electron domains (two bonds, one lone pair). The lone pair pushes the two bonds closer than the ideal $120^\circ$ of a trigonal planar arrangement.

questions.question: Which of the following molecules is distorted by 'Lone Pair - Lone Pair' repulsion?
options: $XeF_2$
questions.explanation: Xenon difluoride has three lone pairs in the equatorial plane. The repulsion between these lone pairs keeps them $120^\circ$ apart, while the bonds are pushed to a $180^\circ$ axial arrangement.

scoreMessages.90: Brilliant! You truly understand the subtle pressures within a molecule.
scoreMessages.70: Great job. You have a solid grasp of why 'ideal' isn't always 'real'.
scoreMessages.50: Good effort. Focus on the fact that lone pairs always 'win' the space battle.
scoreMessages.0: Review the relative strengths of electron group repulsions to see how they push bonds.
